summary: (Internal) Examines aligned contigs from local assemblies and calls structural variants

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: Uncertainty in overlap of assembled breakpoints and evidence target links.
arguments.name: --assembly-imprecise-evidence-overlap-uncertainty

arguments.summary: maximum number of bytes to read from a file into each partition of reads. Setting this higher will result in fewer partitions. Note that this will not be equal to the size of the partition in memory. Defaults to 0, which uses the default split size (determined by the Hadoop input format, typically the size of one HDFS block).
arguments.name: --bam-partition-size

arguments.summary: External CNV calls file. Should be single sample VCF, and contain only confident autosomal non-reference CNV calls (for now).
arguments.name: --cnv-calls

arguments.summary: Spark properties to set on the Spark context in the format <property>=<value>
arguments.name: --conf

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM splitting index (SBI) when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-splitting-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: Run interpretation tool in debug mode (more information print to screen)
arguments.name: --debug-mode

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: Number of pieces of imprecise evidence necessary to call a variant in the absence of an assembled breakpoint.
arguments.name: --imprecise-variant-evidence-threshold

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: Maximum size deletion to call based on imprecise evidence without corroborating read depth evidence
arguments.name: --max-callable-imprecise-deletion-size

arguments.summary: Minimum flanking alignment length
arguments.name: --min-align-length

arguments.summary: Minimum mapping quality of evidence assembly contig
arguments.name: --min-mq

arguments.summary: For tools that shuffle data or write an output, sets the number of reducers. Defaults to 0, which gives one partition per 10MB of input.
arguments.name: --num-reducers

arguments.summary: prefix for discovery (non-genotyped) VCF; sample name will be appended after the provided argument, followed by "_inv_del_ins.vcf"
arguments.name: --output

arguments.summary: when writing a bam, in single sharded mode this directory to write the temporary intermediate output shards, if not specified .parts/ will be used
arguments.name: --output-shard-tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Name of the program running
arguments.name: --program-name

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence file
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: For tools that write an output, write the output in multiple pieces (shards)
arguments.name: --sharded-output

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: URL of the Spark Master to submit jobs to when using the Spark pipeline runner.
arguments.name: --spark-master

arguments.summary: Spark verbosity. Overrides --verbosity for Spark-generated logs only. Possible values: {ALL, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL, OFF, TRACE}
arguments.name: --spark-verbosity

arguments.summary: Granularity to use when writing a splitting index, one entry will be put into the index every n reads where n is this granularity value. Smaller granularity results in a larger index with more available split points.
arguments.name: --splitting-index-granularity

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Breakpoint padding for evaluation against truth data.
arguments.name: --truth-interval-padding

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use NIO or the Hadoop filesystem (default) for reading files. (Note that the Hadoop filesystem is always used for writing files.)
arguments.name: --use-nio

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
(Internal) Examines aligned contigs from local assemblies and calls structural variants

This tool is used in development and should not be of interest to most researchers. It packages structural variant calling as a separate tool, independent of the generation of local assemblies. Most researchers will run StructuralVariationDiscoveryPipelineSpark, which both generates local assemblies of interesting genomic regions, and then calls structural variants from these assemblies.

This tool takes a SAM/BAM/CRAM containing the alignments of assembled contigs from local assemblies and searches it for split alignments indicating the presence of structural variations. To do so the tool parses primary and supplementary alignments; secondary alignments are ignored. To be considered valid evidence of an SV, two alignments from the same contig must have mapping quality 60, and both alignments must have length greater than or equal to min-alignment-length. Imprecise variants with approximate locations are also called.

The input file is typically the output file produced by FindBreakpointEvidenceSpark.

Inputs

  • An input file of assembled contigs or long reads aligned to reference.
  • The reference to which the contigs have been aligned.

Output

  • A vcf file describing the discovered structural variants.

Usage example

   gatk DiscoverVariantsFromContigAlignmentsSAMSpark \
     -I assemblies.sam \
     -R reference.2bit \
     -O structural_variants.vcf

This tool can be run without explicitly specifying Spark options. That is to say, the given example command without Spark options will run locally. See Tutorial#10060 for an example of how to set up and run a Spark tool on a cloud Spark cluster.

Notes

The reference is broadcast by Spark, and must therefore be a .2bit file due to current restrictions.
name: DiscoverVariantsFromContigAlignmentsSAMSpark
